articles.title: Nasa's first female space commander: I didn't want people to say 'the woman made a mistake'
articles.summary: The BBC speaks to astronaut Eileen Collins, the first woman to pilot and command a spacecraft.
articles.content:
Nasa's first female space commander: I didn't want people to say 'the woman made a mistake'

2 hours ago Share Save Rebecca Morelle Science Editor and Alison Francis Senior Science Journalist Share Save

Tony Jolliffe/ BBC News From a very young age, Eileen Collins wanted to be an astronaut

She's the astronaut who smashed through the glass ceiling. And kept on going. Eileen Collins made history as the first woman to pilot and command a spacecraft - but despite her remarkable achievements, not everyone will know her name. Now a feature-length documentary called Spacewoman, which chronicles her trailblazing career, looks set to change that. We meet Collins at London's Science Museum. She's softly spoken, warm and very down to earth - but you quickly get a sense of her focus and determination. She clearly has inner steel. "I was reading a magazine article on the Gemini astronauts. I was probably nine years old, and I thought that's the coolest thing. That's what I want to do," she says. "Of course, there were no women astronauts back then. But I just thought, I'll be a lady astronaut."

NASA Nasa's Space Shuttle programme flew for three decades

But that little girl set her sights even higher - she wanted to be at the controls of a spacecraft. And the only way to achieve this was to join the military and become a test pilot. In the Air Force, she stood out from the crowd and was selected to join the astronaut programme. She was to fly Space Shuttles - Nasa's reusable "space planes". She knew the eyes of the world were on her when her first mission launched in 1995. "As the first woman to pilot the Space Shuttle, I worked very hard at that because I didn't want people to say, 'Oh look, the woman has made a mistake'. Because it wasn't just about me, it was about the women to follow me," she says. "And I wanted there to be a reputation for women pilots that was: 'Hey, they're really good'."

Eileen Collins Eileen Collins with her young daughter Bridget

She was so good in fact that she was soon promoted to commander, in another space first. Collins was also a parent to two young children. The fact that she was a working wife and mother was frequently brought up in press conferences at the time, with some journalists seemingly astonished that she could be both. But Collins says being a mum and a commander were "the two best jobs in the world". "But I'm going to tell you it is harder to be a parent than to be a space shuttle commander," she laughs. "The best training I ever had for being a commander was being a parent - because you have to learn how to say no to people."

NASA A huge investigation was launched after the Columbia disaster

Nasa's Space Shuttles, which flew for three decades, reached breathtaking highs, but also some terrible lows. In 1986, the Challenger spacecraft suffered a catastrophic failure seconds after launching, killing all seven crew members on board. And in 2003, the Columbia shuttle broke up in the skies over Texas at the end of its mission, killing its crew of seven as well. A piece of insulating foam on Columbia's fuel tank broke loose during launch, damaging the heat shield with devastating results. Columbia was unable to withstand the fiery re-entry into the Earth's atmosphere, disintegrating as the world watched on in horror. Collins shakes her head at the memory of the disaster, and of the friends whose lives were lost. But with her job as commander, she had to pick up the mantle - she was to be in charge of the shuttle's following flight. Did she think about quitting at that point? "People throughout the shuttle programme were counting on the commander to stick with it," she says quietly. "I think quitting the mission would have been the opposite of brave… and I wanted to be a brave leader. I wanted to be a confident leader. I wanted to instill that confidence in other people."

But when her mission finally took to the skies in 2005, the nightmare scenario happened again. A chunk of foam broke away during launch. This time, though, there was a plan in place to check the damage. But it meant undertaking one of the riskiest maneuvers in space history. Collins had to pilot the shuttle through a 360 degree flip while flying beneath the International Space Station. It allowed colleagues on the orbiting lab to photograph the craft's underside and check if the heatshield had been breached. "There were engineers and managers saying it couldn't be done, all these reasons why it was too dangerous," she says. "I listened to the discussion, they knew I was the commander, and I said: 'It sounds like we can do it'."

NASA Collins remained cool and calm under pressure

With her hands steady at the controls, her voice calm as she spoke to mission control, Collins piloted the craft through a slow, graceful somersault. With the shuttle's underside now visible, the damage was quickly spotted - and a spacewalk was carried out to repair it. It meant Collins and her crew would make it safely home. This was Collins's last flight. She tells us that she always planned to stop after her fourth mission - to give others a chance to go to space. And she's watched plenty of astronauts follow in her footsteps. Does she have any advice for the next generation dreaming of the stars? "Do your homework, listen to your teacher, pay attention in class and read books, and that will give you something to focus on," she says in a matter-of-fact way.

articles.personality_title: Eileen Collins: NASA’s first female space commander breaks barriers with calm leadership
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – For many years, space missions were led only by men. Eileen Collins dreamed of becoming an astronaut from a young age, even though no women had flown spacecraft when she was a child. To reach her goal, she joined the Air Force and became a test pilot before being selected by NASA.

**What happened** – In 1995, Eileen Collins became the first woman to pilot a NASA Space Shuttle. Later, she made history again by becoming the first female commander of a shuttle mission. During her career, she faced difficult challenges, including the aftermath of the Columbia disaster and risky in-space repairs. In 2005, she successfully piloted a risky flip maneuver to check for damage on her shuttle, helping her crew return safely.

**Impact** – Collins’s achievements showed that women could lead complex and dangerous space missions with skill and calm. She worked hard to prove that women astronauts were just as capable as men, helping change how people saw female pilots. Her leadership inspired many young girls and boys interested in science and space.

**What's next step** – Collins retired after her fourth mission to allow new astronauts to explore space. She encourages future generations to study hard, listen to teachers, and keep learning. Her story is now shared widely through a new documentary, helping more people learn about her pioneering work.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Eileen Collins’s historic role as NASA’s first female space commander proved that determination and calm leadership can break barriers in space exploration.

articles.personality_title_es: Eileen Collins: la primera mujer comandante espacial de la NASA rompe barreras con liderazgo tranquilo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante muchos años, las misiones espaciales fueron dirigidas solo por hombres. Eileen Collins soñaba con ser astronauta desde niña, aunque no había mujeres que volaran naves espaciales cuando era pequeña. Para lograr su meta, se unió a la Fuerza Aérea y se convirtió en piloto de pruebas antes de ser seleccionada por la NASA.

**Qué pasó** – En 1995, Eileen Collins se convirtió en la primera mujer en pilotar un transbordador espacial de la NASA. Más tarde, hizo historia otra vez al convertirse en la primera comandante femenina de una misión espacial. Durante su carrera, enfrentó grandes desafíos, como las consecuencias del desastre del Columbia y reparaciones riesgosas en el espacio. En 2005, pilotó con éxito una maniobra peligrosa para revisar daños en su nave, ayudando a que su tripulación regresara segura.

**Impacto** – Los logros de Collins demostraron que las mujeres podían liderar misiones espaciales complejas y peligrosas con habilidad y tranquilidad. Trabajó duro para mostrar que las astronautas eran tan capaces como los hombres, cambiando la forma en que la gente veía a las pilotos femeninas. Su liderazgo inspiró a muchos niños y niñas interesados en la ciencia y el espacio.

**Próximo paso** – Collins se retiró después de su cuarta misión para dar oportunidad a nuevos astronautas. Anima a las futuras generaciones a estudiar, escuchar a sus maestros y seguir aprendiendo. Su historia ahora se comparte más gracias a un nuevo documental, ayudando a que más personas conozcan su trabajo pionero.

**Una frase clave** – El papel histórico de Eileen Collins como la primera mujer comandante espacial de la NASA demostró que la determinación y un liderazgo tranquilo pueden romper barreras en la exploración espacial.

articles.title: A distant comet is forming new rings while we watch in real time
articles.summary: The comet-like object Chiron has been caught in the process of forming new rings, which could help us understand how these complex systems work
articles.content:
The comet-like object Chiron has been caught in the process of forming new rings, which could help us understand how these complex systems work

Illustration of Chiron’s rings Dan Durda

For the first time, astronomers are watching a ring system form in real time. The rings in question encircle Chiron, a comet-like object that takes a path around the sun between the orbits of Saturn and Uranus. Every time we look at Chiron, its rings seem to be a little different.

Chiron isn’t the first small object we have observed rings around: the asteroid Chariklo and dwarf planets Haumea and Quaoar also have small ring systems. All of these rings were spotted through a method called stellar occultation, which involves waiting for the object to pass in front of a distant star and then creating a map of how the star’s light is blocked by orbiting material.

“There are only maybe 20 objects that have been observed through stellar occultations, so observing four of them with rings is high statistics,” says Bruno Sicardy at the Paris Observatory in France. “There are hundreds or thousands of bodies out there, so there must be hundreds of ring systems.” He expects we will find many more in the coming years.

Sicardy and his colleagues examined a stellar occultation that occurred in 2023 to nail down the structure of the rings around Chiron. While previous observations revealed the probable presence of three rings, this new observation showed an additional disc of material enveloping those rings and extending further from Chiron’s surface, plus another ring even further out that has never been seen before.

“Nature is showing us a ring in the formation stage, which is very lucky for us, because when we look at Saturn’s rings or Uranus’s rings, or even Chariklo’s rings, they basically always stay the same,” says Sicardy.

Free newsletter Sign up to Launchpad Bring the galaxy to your inbox every month, with the latest space news, launches and astronomical occurrences from New Scientist’s Leah Crane. Sign up to newsletter

There are many different ways rings can form, but watching their formation as it progresses could help us understand them far more deeply than we do now. “[This could] shed light on the specific conditions that allow the formation, persistence or dissipation of rings, and may ultimately explain why such systems are only found in the cold, icy regions of the solar system,” says team member Chrystian Pereira at the National Observatory of Brazil.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific observation of a ring system forming in real time around the comet-like object Chiron, providing new insights into ring formation processes in the solar system. This discovery has broad implications for understanding planetary ring systems and the conditions in cold, icy regions of space, benefiting the general scientific community and public knowledge.
articles.personality_title: Astronomers watch new rings form around distant comet-like object Chiron
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Chiron is a small object in space that moves between the orbits of Saturn and Uranus. It is similar to a comet and has rings around it, like some planets and other small bodies in our solar system. Scientists study these rings to learn more about how they form and change.

**What happened** – In 2023, astronomers observed Chiron as it passed in front of a distant star, a method called stellar occultation. This allowed them to see the rings blocking the star’s light and discover new details. They found that Chiron’s rings are changing and forming right now, with new rings appearing further from its surface.

**Impact** – This is the first time scientists have seen rings form around a small object in real time. Usually, rings like those around Saturn or Uranus stay the same for a long time. Watching these new rings develop helps us understand how rings start and why they exist mostly in cold, icy parts of space.

**What’s next step** – Researchers will continue to observe Chiron and other similar objects to learn more about ring formation. They expect to find many more ring systems around small bodies in the solar system, which could reveal why rings form and how they change.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists are witnessing new rings form around Chiron, offering fresh clues about how ring systems develop in our solar system.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les astronomes observent la formation de nouvelles anneaux autour de l'objet cométaire Chiron
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Chiron est un petit objet spatial qui se déplace entre les orbites de Saturne et d’Uranus. Il ressemble à une comète et possède des anneaux, comme certaines planètes et petits corps du système solaire. Les scientifiques étudient ces anneaux pour mieux comprendre leur formation et leur évolution.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En 2023, des astronomes ont observé Chiron passer devant une étoile lointaine, une méthode appelée occultation stellaire. Cela leur a permis de voir les anneaux bloquer la lumière de l’étoile et de découvrir de nouveaux détails. Ils ont trouvé que les anneaux de Chiron changent et se forment actuellement, avec de nouveaux anneaux apparaissant plus loin de sa surface.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois que des scientifiques voient des anneaux se former en temps réel autour d’un petit objet. Habituellement, les anneaux comme ceux de Saturne ou Uranus restent stables longtemps. Observer ces nouveaux anneaux en formation aide à comprendre comment ils commencent et pourquoi ils se trouvent surtout dans les régions froides et glacées de l’espace.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs continueront d’observer Chiron et d’autres objets similaires pour mieux comprendre la formation des anneaux. Ils s’attendent à découvrir de nombreux autres systèmes d’anneaux autour de petits corps du système solaire, ce qui pourrait expliquer leur origine et leur évolution.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les scientifiques assistent à la formation de nouveaux anneaux autour de Chiron, offrant des indices précieux sur le développement des systèmes d’anneaux dans notre système solaire.
articles.personality_title_es: Astrónomos observan la formación de nuevos anillos alrededor del objeto cometa Chiron
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Chiron es un pequeño objeto en el espacio que se mueve entre las órbitas de Saturno y Urano. Es similar a un cometa y tiene anillos, como algunos planetas y otros cuerpos pequeños del sistema solar. Los científicos estudian estos anillos para entender mejor cómo se forman y cambian.

**Qué pasó** – En 2023, los astrónomos observaron a Chiron pasar frente a una estrella lejana, usando un método llamado ocultación estelar. Esto les permitió ver cómo los anillos bloqueaban la luz de la estrella y descubrir nuevos detalles. Encontraron que los anillos de Chiron están cambiando y formándose ahora mismo, con nuevos anillos apareciendo más lejos de su superficie.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que los científicos ven anillos formarse en un objeto pequeño en tiempo real. Normalmente, los anillos como los de Saturno o Urano permanecen iguales por mucho tiempo. Ver estos nuevos anillos en formación ayuda a entender cómo comienzan y por qué existen principalmente en las regiones frías y heladas del espacio.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores seguirán observando a Chiron y a otros objetos similares para aprender más sobre la formación de anillos. Esperan encontrar muchos más sistemas de anillos alrededor de cuerpos pequeños en el sistema solar, lo que podría explicar por qué se forman y cómo cambian.

**Resumen en una frase** – Los científicos están viendo cómo se forman nuevos anillos alrededor de Chiron, ofreciendo nuevas pistas sobre el desarrollo de sistemas de anillos en nuestro sistema solar.
